title: About
text:
I am a current second year master of science (ScM) student studying infectious disease epidemiology at the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. I previously received a BA in Government with a focus on international relations from Cornell University. While in undergrad, I competed on the Cornell University Sailing Team from 2012 to 2016.
I am interested in infectious disease modelling and its applications in the fight against vaccine preventable diseases. I am specifically interested in researching influenza viruses and their pandemic potential.
I am currently working for the JHU Department of Epidemiology on a COVID-19, Cholera, and Hepatitis E serologic survey of Chittagong Bangladesh. This work is associated with my masters thesis, focused on exploring Cholera related healthcare seeking in the study cohort. I also work at the JHU’s International Vaccine Access Center on several projects related to COVID-19 modeling and COVID-19 vaccine health systems. I have previously volunteered over 200 hrs in clinical settings, interned at the WHO, and worked in project management on the construction of a 50 story skyscraper.

title: Taner Bertuna’s Website
text:
Welcome to Taner Bertuna’s personal website!!
I am an aspiring epidemiologist with a diverse set of experiences and passions. In my personal life, I love to sail competitively on the Chesapeake Bay and hike with my partner and my dog.

title: Example Analysis
text:
(“Introduction to Palmerpenguins” n.d.)

Objective
The goal of the analysis is to describe variability in penguin body mass per the Palmer Penguins data set. This is intended to be viewed by anyone that is interested in penguin body mass dynamics.


The data


Data dictionary:
The data set includes measured information for a cohort of penguins. The data set includes information for 344 penguins, including their location, date of observation, biometric data, and general comments.
Can be accessed at this link:
https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/master/data/2020/2020-07-28/readme.md
(DataSets 2022)


Data exploration:






Note



Remove comments, delta 15 and delta 13 columns





What is the mean body weight of each of the three species?


# A tibble: 3 x 2
  Species                                   mean_mass
  <chr>                                         <dbl>
1 Adelie Penguin (Pygoscelis adeliae)            8.16
2 Chinstrap penguin (Pygoscelis antarctica)      8.23
3 Gentoo penguin (Pygoscelis papua)             11.2 


What is the mean body weight for each sex?


# A tibble: 2 x 2
  Sex    mean_mass
  <chr>      <dbl>
1 FEMALE      8.51
2 MALE       10.0 


What is the mean body weight of of the penguins on each island?


# A tibble: 3 x 2
  Island    mean_mass
  <chr>         <dbl>
1 Biscoe        10.4 
2 Dream          8.19
3 Torgersen      8.17




Plots
(“Create Elegant Data Visualisations Using the Grammar of Graphics” n.d.)

penguins_data %>% 
  group_by(Species, Sex) %>%
  filter(!is.na(`Body Mass (lbs)`)) %>%
  filter(!is.na(Sex)) %>%
  summarize(mean_mass = mean(`Body Mass (lbs)`)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = Sex, y = mean_mass,  fill = Species)) +
  geom_bar(position="dodge", stat="identity") + 
  ylab("Mean Body Mass in lbs") + 
  ggtitle("Table 1: Penguin Body Mass by Sex, Broken Down by Species") + 
  labs(subtitle = "Males seem to have higher body masses for all species")

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Species'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.











Note



The grey bands mark the bounds of the LOESS smoothed lines’ 95% confidence interval.




`geom_smooth()` using formula 'y ~ x'







`summarise()` has grouped output by 'Island'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.





Linear regression with body mass in lbs as dependent variable and sex as independent variable (“R Linear Regression Tutorial: Lm Function in r with Code Examples” n.d.)



Call:
lm(formula = `Body Mass (lbs)` ~ Sex, data = penguins_data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-2.8565 -1.3133 -0.5231  1.6264  3.8676 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept)   8.5148     0.1253  67.963  < 2e-16 ***
SexMALE       1.5067     0.1764   8.542  4.9e-16 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 1.609 on 331 degrees of freedom
  (11 observations deleted due to missingness)
Multiple R-squared:  0.1806,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.1781 
F-statistic: 72.96 on 1 and 331 DF,  p-value: 4.897e-16




Note that the p value for sex is statistically significant
The analysis looked at three variables to see if they has a statistically significant impact on the body mass of the palmer penguins. Looking at sex, table 1 indicates that males have a larger average body mass as compared to females, across all three species’. This is supported by a simple uni variate linear regression that indicates that males weight about 4.5 lbs more than females (this association is statistically significant with a p value of < 0.000). Looking at flipper length, table 2 indicates that there is a clear positive association between length and body mass for all three species and that the association is more pronounced for Gentoo penguins. Finally, table 3 shows that the only penguin species found across all three islands (Adelie penguins) do not vary in weight across the islands, indicating that island verity does not effect average weight for the species in question.






Note



Libraries used: ggplot2, tidyverse, RefManageR, bibtex, and palmerspenguins







References

“Create Elegant Data Visualisations Using the Grammar of Graphics.” n.d. Accessed November 10, 2022. https://ggplot2.tidyverse.org/.


DataSets. 2022. R for Data Science Online Learning Community. https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/blob/840f418efda3ee1a39c1d1e24bf23bc083a5b7e5/data/2020/2020-07-28/readme.md.


“Introduction to Palmerpenguins.” n.d. Accessed November 10, 2022. https://allisonhorst.github.io/palmerpenguins/articles/intro.html.


“R Linear Regression Tutorial: Lm Function in r with Code Examples.” n.d. Accessed November 10, 2022. https://www.datacamp.com/tutorial/linear-regression-R.
